item.title: European Gas Price Falls Further on Warmer Weather, Ample Flows
item.description: European natural-gas prices fell below 30 euros a megawatt-hour as forecasts of warmer temperatures eased concerns over low storage levels.

item.title: The Phantom Stealth Fighter That Exposes Europe’s Deep Divisions Over Defense
item.description: Duplicated efforts, a fragmented industry and soured collaborations are among the reasons the region isn’t getting more bang for its defense buck.
item.dc:creator: Robbie Gramer

item.title: A Giant ISIS Detention Facility Comes Apart in Syria’s Desert
item.description: Syria’s government is moving to close the facility and relocate detainees after escapes and rioting.
item.dc:creator: Jared Malsin

item.title: U.S. Envoy Draws Belgium’s Rebuke Over Antisemitism Comments
item.description: The diplomatic dust-up marked the third recent spat between a U.S. ambassador and European host capital.
item.dc:creator: Kim Mackrael

item.title: Opinion | Europe Fills U.S. Aid Loss to Ukraine
item.description: As U.S. aid falls 99%, the Continent steps up to provide weapons.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: Opinion | Iran Wants Trump to Pull an Obama
item.description: The regime is safe when the U.S. focuses merely on its nuclear program, as it claims ‘progress’ in Geneva negotiations.

item.title: U.S. Hardens Allegation That China Conducted a Secret Nuclear Test
item.description: New seismic data points to a detonation in northwest China, the U.S. said.

item.title: Vance Says Iran Is Ignoring Core U.S. Demands in Talks
item.description: Washington said it agreed to give Tehran two weeks to close the gaps.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: Japan Plans $36 Billion in U.S. Investments Under Trump Administration Deal
item.description: Projects include critical minerals, oil and gas infrastructure and power generation, U.S. officials say.
item.dc:creator: Gavin Bade

item.title: Peru Ousts Another Embattled President
item.description: The nation’s congress voted to remove President José Jerí, just four months after the 39-year-old leader had taken office.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Dubé

item.title: Opinion | Boris Johnson: Put Up or Put a Sock in It, Europe
item.description: Continental leaders talk big about autonomy and independence from the U.S., but it’s all bluster.

item.title: India Seizes Sanctioned Shadow Fleet Tankers Amid Trade Thaw With U.S.
item.description: The move marks New Delhi’s first direct support of U.S. efforts to crack down on the so-called dark fleet.
item.dc:creator: Benoit Faucon

item.title: India’s Adani Group to Invest $100 Billion in AI Infrastructure
item.description: The conglomerate’s investment would be a boost to the country’s ambitions to become a global leader in artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Kosaku Narioka

item.title: Tour Guides Accused of Scamming the Louvre Out of $12 Million
item.description: Guides who escorted Chinese tourists through the museum allegedly reused tickets and bribed security to look the other way.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Dalton

item.title: U.S. Plans to Deploy More Missile Systems in the Philippines, Challenging China
item.description: The commitment to a key Asian ally coincides with increased pressure on other defense partners.
item.dc:creator: Gabriele Steinhauser

item.title: German Economic Sentiment Slips Unexpectedly
item.description: Confidence among investors fell this month, highlighting the fragile nature of an anticipated rebound in Europe’s largest economy this year.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Britain’s Monarchy Can’t Escape the Shadow of the Epstein Scandal
item.description: Emails show the extent of the disgraced financier’s relations with the former Prince Andrew and his ex-wife.
item.dc:creator: Margot Patrick

item.title: In Iran, Payment Plans for Groceries Signal a Deepening Economic Crisis
item.description: Tehran’s crackdown on protests and the threats of new U.S. strikes are weighing on the currency and stifling economic activity.
item.dc:creator: Jared Malsin

item.title: Giorgia Meloni’s Mission: Persuading Trump and Europe to Be Friends
item.description: The Italian leader is trying to stop the trans-Atlantic rift from becoming a divorce, even as voters and European peers sour on the alliance.
item.dc:creator: Marcus Walker

item.title: Opinion | Jimmy Lai and Trump’s Nobel Peace Prize
item.description: The president will deserve the award if he gets the publisher freed from prison.
item.dc:creator: William McGurn

item.title: Opinion | Iran’s Crisis Is Trump’s Sweet Spot
item.description: For him, the worst thing about the standoff may be that it can’t last forever.
item.dc:creator: Walter Russell Mead

item.title: Opinion | Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez Does Geopolitics
item.description: She grabs attention in Munich but stumbles over Taiwan 101.
item.dc:creator: The Editorial Board

item.title: The Canada School Shooting Touched Almost Everyone at a U.S.-Backed Coal Company
item.description: Many of the victims in the hamlet of Tumbler Ridge, B.C., have links to Conuma Resources, which temporarily stopped mining last week.
item.dc:creator: James T. Areddy

item.title: The Newest Old Tech in Warfare: Balloons
item.description: Reinvented as long-range drone-launchers, high-altitude balloons are extending the reach of Ukrainian attacks and American surveillance.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Michaels

item.title: Eurozone Industry Stumbles, But Outlook Remains Bright
item.description: Industrial production fell 1.4% in December, halting three consecutive months of expansion after output declined in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Don Nico Forbes

item.title: Millions Face Starvation in Congo. Their New Rulers Are to Blame.
item.description: The M23 militia has tried to assert itself as the government in and around Goma. It is failing badly.

item.title: A Defector Explains the Remote-Work Scam Helping North Korea Pay for Nukes
item.description: Kim Jong Un’s cyber operatives have faked their way into IT jobs at American firms and elsewhere, pocketing big revenue for the regime.

item.title: Canada to Prioritize Domestic Firms in Defense-Spending Plan Amid U.S. Tension
item.description: Canada is seeking to create 125,000 jobs and increase corporate revenue by billions annually by ensuring domestic firms receive priority from a sizable increase in defense spending.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vieira

item.title: U.S. and Europe, No Longer Kindred Souls, Enter a Marriage of Convenience
item.description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio offered a warmer tone at this year’s Munich Security Conference, but European officials say the trans-Atlantic fissure remains.
item.dc:creator: Yaroslav Trofimov

item.title: Doctors Without Borders Says Gunmen Are Using a Gaza Hospital, Posing Risk to Patients and Staff
item.description: Doctors Without Borders suspended all noncritical care at Nasser Hospital Complex last month after an uptick in what it called unacceptable acts.
item.dc:creator: Dov Lieber

item.title: China Watchers Are Trying to Spot the Next Target of Xi’s Purges
item.description: “Pekingologists” are hunting for clues in seating arrangements and funeral wreaths to determine which officials are in trouble.

item.title: On the Ground With Crews Battling to Keep the Lights On in Ukraine
item.description: Emergency-repair teams and power-station workers fight around the clock to restore power and heating under constant Russian attacks.

item.title: Teen Suspect in Canada Shooting Had Turbulent Life Marred by ‘Nomadic’ Early Years
item.description: Police are still searching for clues as to why the 18-year-old suspect would have turned violent, and how she could have carried out her attack.

item.title: Canada Has a Secessionist Movement on Its Hands. Its Supporters Thank Trump.
item.description: Oil-rich Alberta is poised to hold an independence referendum this year, with the American president’s allies cheering it on.

item.title: Navalny Killed by Poison Frog Toxin, European Governments Say
item.description: The dissident was killed while in Russian custody by a substance that doesn’t occur naturally in Russia, according to the joint investigation.

item.title: Rubio Seeks to Reassure European Allies in Munich Speech
item.description: The secretary of state addressed tensions over tariffs and Ukraine in a speech at trans-Atlantic security conference.

item.title: Saudi Youth Couldn’t Date Openly a Decade Ago. Now Tinder Is Booming.
item.description: Liberalization has opened the door to more casual relationships, but society is still catching up.

item.title: Cuba’s Food and Water Supplies Threatened Under U.S. Pressure, U.N. Says
item.description: Mexico, Chile and other countries said they were rushing aid to the Caribbean island, but economists said it would do little to alleviate the crisis
item.dc:creator: Samantha Pearson

item.title: Germany’s Merz Calls for an Overhaul of the U.S.-Europe Alliance
item.description: The German chancellor said the U.S. and Europe don’t share the same values but should still cooperate on common interests.

item.title: CIA Seeks to Recruit Spies Out of China’s Military Turmoil
item.description: The Central Intelligence Agency posted a YouTube video depicting a Chinese officer’s lament about high-level purges.

item.title: BOE’s Key Rate Is Too Low, But Answer Is Not A Rise, Says Chief Economist
item.description: Huw Pill said inflation can be squeezed out of the economy without a rise in borrowing costs.

item.title: Russia’s Central Bank Cuts Rate Again as Economy Slows
item.description: The central bank lowered its key interest rate for a sixth consecutive meeting, but continued to restrain a slowing economy as the country’s costly war on Ukraine approaches its fourth anniversary.
item.dc:creator: Paul Hannon

item.title: Starlink Shutdown Blunts Russia’s Newest Battlefield Advantage
item.description: The limits have hobbled Russia’s use of drone-mounted terminals that had begun to ravage Ukrainian supply lines.

item.title: U.S. Is Sending Its Largest Warship to the Middle East
item.description: The USS Gerald R. Ford will join another aircraft carrier and nine other warships in the region.

item.title: Japan Seizes Chinese Fishing Boat and Arrests Its Skipper
item.description: The incident comes amid strained relations between Tokyo and Beijing.

item.title: Kim’s Young Daughter Looks More Likely to Be North Korea’s Next Leader
item.description: A new assessment from South Korea’s spy agency adds to speculation that Kim Jong Un might break with tradition by naming a female successor.
item.dc:creator: Timothy W. Martin

item.title: Bangladesh Votes for Old Guard in First Elections After Its Gen-Z Revolution
item.description: Led by Tarique Rahman, the Bangladesh Nationalist Party will form the country’s new government after winning a majority.

item.title: A German General Prepares His Country for War—and the Clock Is Ticking
item.description: Could Russia launch a war across Europe? The Germans aren’t waiting to find out.

item.description: The move affects 100 million users of the Meta-owned app.

item.description: The Trump administration covertly sent terminals into Iran in an effort to keep dissidents online following Tehran’s stifling of internet access.

item.title: U.K. Posts Modest Growth for 2025
item.description: The U.K. economy recorded another year of modest economic growth in 2025 as consumers stayed cautious, unemployment rose and borrowing costs remained high.

item.description: The investigation is set to prolong a fight for control of a key automotive supplier.

item.title: U.K. Government Bonds Enter Period of Political Risk
item.description: The rise in yields reflects worries that a successor to Starmer would be tempted to spend more heavily on public services, pushing government debt higher.

item.title: China’s Consumer Inflation Eases, Producer Prices Stay in Decline
item.description: China’s consumer inflation softened at the start of 2026 after hitting a near three-year high in December, weighed down by falling food prices.

item.title: U.S. to Send 200 Troops to Help Nigeria Fight Islamist Insurgents
item.description: Americans will train local forces, but won’t see combat, officials say.
item.dc:creator: Michael M. Phillips

item.title: Kenya’s Central Bank Cuts Key Lending Rate
item.description: Kenya’s central bank cut its key lending rate as East Africa’s largest economy continued a policy-loosening cycle to boost private-sector lending and economic growth.

item.title: Sterling Stays Weaker Even as U.K. Government Bond Yields Fall Amid Political Uncertainty
item.description: Pressure has mounted on the government over the appointment of Peter Mandelson, former British ambassador to Washington.

item.title: They Came for Its Riches, but Big Business Is Souring on South Africa
item.description: The corporate exodus is accelerating, propelled by a toxic cocktail of corruption, lawlessness and poor infrastructure.

item.title: Uganda’s Central Bank Holds Key Lending Rate at 9.75%
item.description: Uganda’s central bank maintained its key lending rate at 9.75%, citing rising inflationary pressure and high oil prices amid sustained geopolitical uncertainty.

item.title: The U.S. Navy’s New Insurance Policy for War With China Is an Australian Base
item.description: The Pentagon plans to deploy submarines to an expanding facility in allies’ strategy to deter Beijing.

item.description: The allegation comes as the White House pushes Beijing to agree to new nuclear talks after the New Start arms-control deal expired this week.

item.title: Why Big Tech Is Throwing Cash Into India in Quest for AI Supremacy
item.description: Lured by its big, tech-savvy population, Google and other giants are sinking tens of billions into the Indian market.

item.title: Why India Will Struggle to Reduce Its Reliance on Russian Oil
item.description: India relies on Russia for roughly a third of its oil imports, up from just 2% before Russia invaded Ukraine in early 2022.

item.title: Several People Missing After Landslide Buries Campground in New Zealand
item.description: Debris engulfed the site at Mount Maunganui following record rainfall. A government minister said young people were among the missing.

item.title: Can a U.S.-Greenland Partnership Work? Just Look at These Pacific Islands
item.description: U.S. agreements with three island nations have benefited both sides but have also had challenges.
